SAM-III

Apr 27, 2023 • Zhizhong Lu, Wenjian Liao

Rfam ID: RF01767 (SMK box translational riboswitch (SAM-III))


横向排列的点击按钮

Timeline Description Structure&recognition References


Timeline

Start

    Discovered and named SMK box, the S(MK) box represents a new SAM-binding riboswitch

    2006[1]

    Translation control mechanism about S(MK)/SAM-III riboswitch

    2007[2]

    Crystal structures of the SAM-III/S(MK) riboswitch

    2008[3]

    Atomic level understanding of the ligand recognition mechanism of SAM-III riboswitch

    2010[4]

    S(MK) box is a reversible riboswitch

    2010[5]

    Probe the ligand-induced conformational switching mechanism of SAM-III riboswitch

    2011[6]

    Provides a detailed understanding of folded structures of the SAM-III riboswitch in the presence and absence of the ligand, respectively

    2016[8]

    Gaussian-accelerated molecular dynamics simulations were performed to decipher the identification mechanisms of SAM-III (SMK) on ligands SAM, SAH, and EEM

    2022[10]

    This review summarizes the current research progress on these SAM-related riboswitch families

    2023[11]
2023...



Description

 The SMKbox riboswitch (also known as SAM-III) is an RNA element that regulates gene expression in bacteria. The SMK box riboswitch is found in the 5' UTR of the MetK gene in lactic acid bacteria. The structure of this element changes upon binding to S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) to a conformation that blocks the shine-dalgarno sequence and blocks translation of the gene. There are other known SAM-binding riboswitches such as SAM-I and SAM-II, but these appear to share no similarity in sequence or structure to SAM-III. (from WiKi).


Gene association

Pathways for sulphate assimilation and biosynthesis of cysteine and methionine. SAM-III riboswitch (red bar) is involved in multiple gene regulation in the synthetic pathway[1].


Gene regulation

Translation mechanism of the E.faecalis SMK box/SAM-III riboswitch, the AUG start codon of metK is indicated in yellow, SD sequence (green) is accessible for translation initiation[5].



Structure and Ligand recognition

2D representation

Top: Consensus sequence and secondary structure model for the SAM-III riboswitch. Bottom: Secondary structure depictions of the SAM-III riboswitch according to PDB ID: 3e5c.
<< Show big
<< Show big


3D visualisation

2.25-Å resolution crystal structure of an SAM-III riboswitch complexed with S-adenosylmethionine. The figure reference from PDB ID: 3E5C, SAM (shown in sticks) is labeled in red [3].

(Clicking the "Settings/Controls info" to turn Spin off)      
PDBe Molstar






Binding pocket

Left: Surface representation of the binding pocket of the SAM-III riboswitch generated from PDB ID: 3E5C. S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) (shown in sticks) is labeled in red. Right: Hydrogen bonding between SAM and adjacent bases[3].


Ligand recognition

Chemical structures of various compounds used to probe the binding characteristics of the SAM-III riboswitch[6].

[3] Crystal structures of the SAM-III/S(MK) riboswitch reveal the SAM-dependent translation inhibition mechanism.

[4] Atomistic details of the ligand discrimination mechanism of S(MK)/SAM-III riboswitch.

[6] Variable sequences outside the SAM-binding core critically influence the conformational dynamics of the SAM-III/SMK box riboswitch.

[9] Reversible-switch mechanism of the SAM-III riboswitch.

Gong, S., Wang, Y., Wang, Z., Wang, Y., & Zhang, W.

[10] Decoding the identification mechanism of an SAM-III riboswitch on ligands through multiple independent gaussian-accelerated molecular dynamics simulations.
